div.p:
After a long time of uncertainty about my future, I can tell you today that since the 1st of July I am not working in the Botanical Gardens any more, but have got a job in the Botanical Museum, employed as they call me "Rouseabout". As I have mentioned before in my letter to you my boss, Baron von Mueller, has many conflicts with the Government and the consequences are that the Government has decided that he should have nothing more to do with the Gardens. He is now official Government Professor of Botany. But with that position the Government has put him on a higher income. It is now from £600 sterling to £800 sterling. Now he can live in great luxury as he is supposed to be used to in Germany. I was hoping that we all would have got a rise in our Salary, but all our hopes have fallen in to the deep sea. Still, I must not complain I have not a bad job now, my new Boss leaves me alone. I am working on my own the whole week, nobody comes near me till Sundays for inspection. I am in the best of health. I am having my friend, Groener, living with me and we are making us a good time.
following letters do not mention M.
26 March 1884: he says that Groener died last month. He had become an alcoholic 'as so many are doing here'. G's 'work boss' [is that M?] had sent him to WA but he died on the way.
